bill_title: establish an alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program and to make an appropriation therefor.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to establish an alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program and to make an appropriation therefor. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Human Services; (2) "Chemical dependency counselor," "counselor," as the term is defined in § 34-20A-2; (3) "Accredited prevention or treatment facility," as the term is defined in § 34-20A-2; (4) "Qualified alcohol and drug addiction loan forgiveness applicant" "qualified applicant," a person who meets the criteria specified in section 2 of this Act; (5) "Student loan," any federally insured student loan, any education loan provided by this or any other state, or any education loan from any private or public source. A loan is a qualifying loan if the applicant can document that the proceeds of the loan were paid to an educational institution for use in the completion of a postsecondary undergraduate or graduate degree that is directly related to the applicant's employment as a chemical dependency counselor in South Dakota. Section 2. The alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program is hereby established. For purposes of this Act, a qualified alcohol and drug addiction loan forgiveness applicant is a person who: (1) Is a resident of South Dakota; (2) Has successfully completed a four-year academic degree or graduate level academic degree at an accredited college or university located in South Dakota; (3) Has been hired as a full-time chemical dependency counselor by an accredited prevention or treatment facility in South Dakota; (4) Has successfully completed the first six months of full-time employment as a chemical dependency counselor at an accredited prevention or treatment facility in South Dakota and remains in good standing with the facility; (5) Has a current outstanding student loan balance. Section 3. A qualified applicant who is selected for the alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program in accordance with this Act is eligible for payment by the department of a portion of student loans incurred by the applicant for the education necessary to be a chemical dependency counselor if the qualified applicant enters into a contract with the department that requires the qualified applicant to remain employed as a full-time chemical dependency counselor in South Dakota for a period of four consecutive years. A loan forgiveness award under this Act may not be made for a loan that is in default at the time of the application. Loan forgiveness provided under the provisions of this Act may not be concurrently awarded to a recipient of another loan forgiveness program provided by the State of South Dakota. Section 4. Under the alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program, the department may repay a proportional part of the qualified applicant's loan so that the loan may be entirely repaid over four years of full-time staff work. No more than five thousand dollars may be repaid for an applicant in any year, and no more than twenty thousand dollars may be repaid for any applicant. Payments shall be made in accordance with the procedures established by the agency in rules promulgated pursuant to chapter 1-26. Section 5. The contract entered into with the department pursuant to section 3 of this Act is a contract with the State of South Dakota and shall include the following terms: (1) The recipient shall agree to be employed by an accredited prevention or treatment facility located in South Dakota; (2) The recipient shall permit the department to determine compliance with the work requirement and all other terms of the contract; (3) Upon the recipient's death or total or permanent disability, the department shall nullify the service obligation of the recipient; (4) If the recipient is convicted of or pleads guilty or no contest to a felony, the department may terminate the recipient's service in the program and demand repayment of the amount of the loan as of the date of the conviction; (5) Loan recipients who fail to begin or complete the obligations contracted for shall pay to the department the amount of the loan received under the terms of the contract pursuant to this Act. Providing false information or misrepresentation on an application or verification of service is deemed a default. Determination as to the time of the default shall be made by the department. Section 6. Recipients of loan forgiveness awards under this Act shall be those chemical dependency counselors who are working in and who have received a satisfactory rating from an accredited prevention or treatment facility. Counselors shall submit such documentation of eligibility as the department may require in rules promulgated pursuant to chapter 1-26, including documentation to indicate full-time employment with an accredited prevention or treatment facility. The documentation shall be presented to the department in the form of a letter from the applicant's employer stating that the applicant is employed by the accredited prevention or treatment facility and that the applicant performs the applicant's duties in a satisfactory manner. Section 7. The department shall publish a report by July 1, 2008, and every year thereafter for the immediately preceding fiscal year. The annual report shall be submitted to the Governor and to the Legislature and shall describe the operation of the program, including: (1) The number and amount of chemical dependency counselor contracts executed and renewed for alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness applicants; (2) The number of defaulted alcohol and drug addiction counselor contracts, reported by cause; (3) The number of full-time staff employees of accredited prevention or treatment facilities participating in the program, reported type of institution attended; (4) The number and type of enforcement actions taken by the department. Section 8. Loan forgiveness awards under this Act may be made to the extent that funds are appropriated by the Legislature and are sufficient to cover the administration of the program. If funding is insufficient to fully fund administration and all eligible applicants, priority shall be given to renewal applicants. Thereafter, the department shall use a random lottery system for determining which applicants receive loan forgiveness awards. Section 9. There is hereby appropriated from the general fund the sum of three hundred thousand dollars ($ 300,000 ), or so much thereof as may be necessary, to the Department of Human Services to implement the alcohol and drug addiction counselor loan forgiveness program established pursuant to this Act. Section 10. The secretary of human services shall approve vouchers and the state auditor shall draw warrants to pay expenditures authorized by this Act. Section 11. Any amounts appropriated in this Act not lawfully expended or obligated by June 30, 2008, shall revert in accordance with § 4-8-21.
